He always says "I know it's true" when he hears something negative about our work. This makes me feel uncomfortable because I don't want to say anything bad about my boss. Answer: You should definitely speak up! If you don’t, then you’re letting your manager’s behavior affect how you feel about yourself. And this isn’t good for your mental health.
It sounds like you’ve been told that you shouldn’t criticize your manager or anyone else at work. That’s not healthy. Your job is to do your best work, so you need to be able to express your opinions without fear of being criticized. The first step is to talk to someone you trust. Tell them what happened and why you felt uncomfortable saying it. Then ask them to help you figure out how to respond. They might suggest talking to your manager directly, or they may give you some tips on how to handle the situation. Whatever you decide, make sure you take action before you go back to work. Don’t let your manager’s reaction affect your confidence or self-esteem.
If you still feel uncomfortable after talking to someone you trust, try writing down your thoughts and feelings. This can help you process your emotions and come up with a plan to deal with the problem. When you’re ready, share your thoughts with your manager. Explain that you’d like to discuss the issue, and offer to meet with him privately to talk about it. Let him know that you’ll be there to listen and support you. Be prepared to explain why you feel you need to talk to him alone. Ask him to consider whether he wants to hear your side of the story. If he does, agree to meet with him later in private.
